metadata.title: Bluebook All Rules Comprehensive Master JSON
metadata.description: Complete JSON compilation of all Bluebook citation rules extracted from markdown files
metadata.note: This master file contains detailed information for 8 major Bluebook rules

1.rule_title: Structure and Use of Citations - Signals
1.rule_text: Provide citations to authorities so that readers may identify and find those authorities for future research. Citations are made in citation sentences and clauses (rule 1.1) and are introduced by signals. Signals organize authorities and show how those authorities support or relate to a proposition given in the text (rule 1.2).

sub_rules.title: Citation Sentences and Clauses
sub_rules.description: A citation sentence is an independent sentence devoted entirely to citations. A citation clause is a series of citations, separated by semicolons when of the same signal type, that is embedded within a sentence.

sub_rules.title: Introductory Signals
sub_rules.description: Signals introduce citations and indicate the degree of support the cited authority provides for the proposition. They are classified as supportive, comparative, contradictory, or background signals.

sub_rules.title: Order of Signals
sub_rules.description: When multiple signals are used, they appear in a specific order: supportive signals first, then comparative, then contradictory, then background signals.

sub_rules.title: Order of Authorities Within Each Signal
sub_rules.description: Authorities within each signal are separated by semicolons and ordered by importance or helpfulness.

sub_rules.title: Parenthetical Information
sub_rules.description: Explanatory parentheticals may follow citations to clarify relevance, but are not allowed after 'See generally' or standalone 'Cf.'

sub_rules.title: Related Authority
sub_rules.description: Subsequent history and related authority should not be given parenthetically but through explanatory phrases.

supportive.usage: Use when the cited authority is an example of the stated rule
Use when authority states or supports the proposition but was not the source of the proposition
Use when authority directly supports the proposition
Use for authorities with somewhat less direct support than 'See'

supportive.meaning: Indicates useful comparison with some explanation
supportive.usage: Use when comparison between authorities supports the proposition

comparative.usage: Use to introduce first element of comparison

contradictory.usage: Use when authority directly states or clearly supports a contrary proposition
Use when comparison with authority supports a contrary proposition

background.usage: Use for authorities providing helpful background or context

2.rule_text: Legal writing uses four typefaces, though choice of typeface conventions differs between academic writing (Whitepages) and practitioner documents (Bluepages). In law review footnotes, specific typefaces are used for different citation elements: ordinary roman, italics, SMALL CAPS, and LARGE & SMALL CAPS.

sub_rules.title: Typeface Conventions for Law Review Citations (Whitepages)
sub_rules.description: In academic writing, citations use four typefaces: roman, italics, small caps, and large & small caps.

sub_rules.title: Typeface Conventions for Textual Material (Whitepages)
sub_rules.description: In the main text of academic writing, only roman and italics are available.

sub_rules.title: Underlined Type (Bluepages)
sub_rules.description: Court documents use underlining instead of italics in limited contexts.

sub_rules.title: Bolded Type (Bluepages)
sub_rules.description: Bold is used extremely rarely in court documents, only in extraordinary circumstances.

sub_rules.title: Italics and Punctuation
sub_rules.description: Punctuation is italicized only if immediately adjacent to italicized words.

4.rule_text: After a full citation has been provided, subsequent citations to the same authority may use a short form. Three main approaches: (1) Id. for identical references, (2) Supra for previous references (except cases), and (3) case name short forms or author short forms.

sub_rules.title: Id. for Identical References
sub_rules.description: Use 'Id.' when the immediately preceding citation is to the sole authority.

sub_rules.title: Supra for Previous References
sub_rules.description: Use 'Supra' for authorities previously cited (except cases) with the note number.

sub_rules.title: Short Forms by Citation Type
sub_rules.description: Different citation types use different short form conventions.

sub_rules.title: Hereinafter Abbreviations
sub_rules.description: Use 'hereinafter' sparingly for cumbersome titles or multiple works by same author.

id_form.usage: Use when immediately preceding citation is the sole authority
id_form.scope: Same footnote OR immediately following footnote ONLY

supra_form.usage: For previously cited authority (not in immediately preceding footnote)

supra_form.restriction: Cases do NOT use supra - use case name short form instead

6.rule_text: The Bluebook provides comprehensive abbreviation rules for legal citations across multiple tables. Rule 6 governs abbreviations for case names, reporters, jurisdictions, court names, and other legal materials. Key tables include T1 (federal courts/materials), T2 (state courts), T6 (corporate designations), and T10 (geographical terms).

sub_rules.title: Case Name Abbreviations
sub_rules.description: Abbreviate case names per Table T1, omitting first/middle names and 'The' at start.

sub_rules.title: Court Abbreviations
sub_rules.description: Abbreviate court names per Table T1 (federal) and T2 (state).

sub_rules.title: Reporter Abbreviations
sub_rules.description: Abbreviate case reporters per Table T1, including official and unofficial reporters.

sub_rules.title: Geographic Abbreviations
sub_rules.description: Abbreviate geographic terms per Table T10.

sub_rules.title: Institutional Author Abbreviations
sub_rules.description: Abbreviate institutional authors per Table T3.

case_names.abbreviate_designations: Use Table T6 (Co., Inc., Ltd., Corp., etc.)
case_names.omit_other_parties: List only first party on each side of v.

8.rule_text: Specific capitalization rules apply to constitutional amendments, acts, court names, judicial titles, and legal documents. The Bluebook provides detailed guidance on when to capitalize references and when to use lowercase to distinguish specific entities from generic references.

sub_rules.description: Capitalize specific constitutional amendments but not generic amendment references.

sub_rules.title: Acts and Statutes
sub_rules.description: Capitalize specific act and statute names but not generic statute references.

sub_rules.description: Specific rules for capitalizing court names, judge titles, and references to terms of court.

sub_rules.title: Titles of Judges Before Names
sub_rules.description: Capitalize judicial and official titles when they precede a name.

sub_rules.title: Generic References
sub_rules.description: Lowercase judicial and official titles when used generically.

12.rule_text: Cite statutes by their official or popular name (if commonly used) and the published source (code or session law) and year. Federal statutes: cite to the U.S. Code when available: Title U.S.C. § Section (Year). For state statutes: cite to the current code if available or the session law if not codified. Include supplements when applicable.

15.rule_title: Books, Reports, and Other Nonperiodic Materials
15.rule_text: This rule covers how to cite books, treatises, reports, white papers, encyclopedias, dictionaries, and similar non-periodic sources. Include authors as names in full as given on the publication, titles italicized, edition if not first, and year of publication. Publisher information is generally not required for well-known legal publishers but is required for lesser-known works.

sub_rules.title: Author
sub_rules.description: Include the author's full name as it appears on the title page.

sub_rules.title: Editor or Translator
sub_rules.description: Include editor or translator information when relevant.

sub_rules.description: Titles must be italicized with proper capitalization (title case).

sub_rules.title: Edition, Publisher, and Date
sub_rules.description: Include edition information (if not first), year of publication, and publisher when necessary.

sub_rules.description: Citation format for essays, chapters, or articles within edited collections.

sub_rules.description: Citation format for online books and electronic sources.

sub_rules.description: Short form citations after full book citation is provided.

punctuation.rule_text: The Bluebook contains comprehensive punctuation rules governing the proper use of commas, periods, semicolons, colons, parentheses, brackets, dashes, quotation marks, and other punctuation in legal citations and academic writing.

sub_rules.description: Citation clauses set off by commas; multiple authorities separated by commas or semicolons depending on context.
Citation sentences end with periods; no periods after section symbols or in degrees.
Semicolons separate signal groups and multiple authorities within parentheticals.
Court/year information in parentheses; explanatory parentheticals with proper content.
Square brackets for alterations in quotations and for nested parentheticals.
Colons separate titles from subtitles and introduce certain citations.
Em dashes for non-grammatical parentheticals; hyphens for ranges.
Proper quotation mark usage and three-dot ellipsis for omissions.
Proper spacing around all punctuation marks.

comma_rules.citation_clauses: Authorities supporting only part of sentence cited in clauses set off by commas
comma_rules.multiple_citations_same_signal: Separate with commas: See X, Y, and Z
comma_rules.compare_contrast: Separate with semicolons: Compare X, 410 U.S. 113 (1973), with Y, 410 U.S. 179 (1973)
comma_rules.parallel_citations: Separate with commas in periodical citations

period_rules.degrees: Include periods (J.D. not JD, Ph.D. not PhD)

semicolon_rules.parenthetical_citations: Separate multiple authorities in parenthetical with semicolons

parentheses_rules.explanatory: Lowercase letter start unless first word is proper noun
parentheses_rules.no_nested: Use brackets instead of nested parentheses

bracket_rules.nested_parentheticals: Use brackets instead of parentheses: (text [inner text] text)
bracket_rules.translations: Use brackets for descriptive or translated titles
